The '''Bounders''' were responsible for policing the borders of [[the Shire]] and ensuring that outsiders behaved themselves. This was known as 'beating the bounds'. The Bounders was the larger of the two branches of the [[Watch]] (the other being the twelve [[Shirriffs]]).<ref name=shire/> 

The number of Bounders at any given time was varied according to need. In the run up to the [[War of the Ring]] they were greatly increased<ref name=shire>{{FR|Ordering}}</ref> and they were busy as strange persons and creatures approached the borders.<ref>{{FR|Shadow}}</ref>

Unbeknownst to the Hobbits of the Shire this was the first sign that the troubles of the south would soon reach even their borders. [[Ruffians]] and spies of [[Isengard]] and [[Mordor]] began to enter [[Eriador]]. 

==Etymology==
The word means "persons watching the boundaries". 

[[J.R.R. Tolkien|Tolkien]] noted that the word was rare, probably because in the late 19th century slang it meant an offensively pushing and in-bred man.<ref name="Nomen">{{HM|N}}, pp. 753-4</ref>

==Portrayal in adaptations==
'''2001: ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring]]'':'''
:A Bounder holding a lantern, played by [[Ian Mune]], confronts a [[Nazgûl|Black Rider]] in the night. He calls out "Who goes there?". The Nazgûl does not slow down and decapitates the Bounder with his blade.

'''2003: [[Pán prsteňov (2001-2003 Slovak radio series)|''Pán prsteňov'' (2001-2003 Slovak radio series)]]:'''
:The voice of an unnamed bounder is provided by Karol Čálik. This bounder character appears in the final episode of the series, in the part of the storyline that adapts the Scouring of the Shire.
